Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: ISN: A Data Analytic Approach to Understanding Human Trafficking Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human trafficking poses a grave threat to national and international security of many countries, including the United States. Human trafficking is the criminal commercial exchange and exploitation of humans for monetary gain or benefit, and is a prevalent and malicious human rights issue as well as a driver of transnational crime. Because human trafficking occurs within illicit supply networks that are hidden from the public eye, insights into the structure and characteristics of human trafficking networks are currently limited. Operations research models have the potential to dramatically improve our ability to disrupt human trafficking networks by increasing the efficiency of limited anti-trafficking resources, but their impact remains largely dormant and unexplored, as the structure and linkages of human trafficking networks is little understood. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will address operational methods to understand and mitigate human trafficking by studying border control and transit center intercept data to identify key aspects of labor and sex trafficking networks from the perspective of traffickers and victims. The data analysis and operational methods will be developed and evaluated by a transdisciplinary team of operations research, human trafficking, and law enforcement experts. New insights into the composition of both labor and sex trafficking networks will enhance related analytical models by better understanding the similarities and key differences with traditional supply chain networks.


This award will support research to formulate high fidelity spatiotemporal analytical models of cross-border human trafficking networks. The methods developed will combine data science and social science approaches and will incorporate different geographic and social network topologies, accounting for regional, cultural and population heterogeneity. Six years of cross-border interception data has been collected, consisting of over 350 data fields with detailed victim and trafficker demographic information, origin and destination points, recruitment methods and transit routes. Analytical results will be informed by qualitative ethnographic techniques that describe recruitment tactics, and regional and cultural nuances. Insights from this analysis will serve as platforms on which to construct context-informed models for operations researchers working in the domain of human trafficking, and are expected to help inform policy makers that oversee resource allocation in border control and law enforcement agencies, as well as anti-trafficking organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human trafficking is the commercial exchange and exploitation of humans for monetary gain or benefit, and is a prevalent and malicious global human rights issue. As human trafficking activities are largely hidden from the public, insights into the structure and characteristics of illicit human trafficking networks are currently limited. Operations Research (OR) models have the potential to dramatically improve the disruption of human trafficking networks. Yet, their impact remains largely dormant and unexplored, as the composition of these networks is little understood. The potential impact of OR is further hindered by historical tendencies to focus on financial metrics rather than incorporating key aspects from the broader spectrum of complex societal issues. A critical first step in using OR methodologies to disrupt human trafficking operations is thus understanding the unique, differentiating features of illicit  trafficking activities from traditional OR applications. Just as important is the subsequent study of how to incorporate such features into OR modeling efforts in a way that the models more accurately reflect reality and are best positioned for societal impact.

Human trafficking responses are divided broadly into two categories: pre-and post-trafficking intervention. This award focused primarily on transit monitoring, a pre-trafficking intervention premised on the notion that it is possible to identify potential trafficking victims while they are in transit, and before they are exploited by placing trained staff at strategic transit points to identify the necessary indicators and intercept these individuals. Unlike post-trafficking interventions, transit monitoring has the obvious advantage of preventing exploitation.

 

The project goal was to establish how the complexities of human trafficking activities can be incorporated into traditional OR methodologies. The project had two objectives: (1) learn from transit monitoring intercept data to identify key aspects of trafficking supply chain activities, and (2) prioritize adaptations and advancements in OR Models to combat human trafficking.

 

To achieve these objectives, the project built a collaborative team of criminal justice scholars, anti-trafficking non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and operations researchers to identify the nuances of human trafficking activity that need to be incorporated into mathematical modeling efforts aimed at disrupting illicit networks.

 

The team completed all project objectives, including the following outcomes:

 

1)       Create a data-driven evidence base. Six-years of intercept data were cleaned and analyzed for demographic, temporal, geographic and recruitment patterns. The data used came from two standardized surveys (6,500 and 3,500 responses, respectively). Consisting of over 350 data fields, the data was incomplete,  and noisy prior to cleaning. Visualizations were produced to serve as a starting point for conversations between anti-trafficking organizations, criminal justice and OR researchers.  While the project initially centered on analyzing border interception data between India and Nepal, the award enabled collaborations, explorations and interaction that stretched beyond the initial geographical focus.

 

2)       Establish an interdisciplinary team. A working collaboration between the OR and anti-trafficking communities was established. The OR researchers learned about the potential for using data analytics and mathematical modeling for applications in social justice and for improving the well-being of at-risk individuals. Trafficking researchers learned how OR and data science can increase the effectiveness of resource allocation decisions in their field.  Through this collaboration, pressing operational issues for the trafficking response community, and how these issues could possibly be addressed using mathematical modeling and algorithms, were identified. The project grant established a foundation for future collaborations. 

 

 

3)       Develop a proof-of-concept application of OR to anti-trafficking activity. The team constructed a data envelopment analysis (DEA) model for the partnering NGO. This mathematical model compared   transit monitoring stations to evaluate their relative efficiency, compared rankings of station performance, and developed recommendations to improve efficiency.

 

4)       Dissemination of findings.   During the grant, the team presented findings to diverse audiences and prepared manuscripts for publication related to the collective understanding of how analytical modeling can be used in the context of human trafficking.

 

5)       Student Development. Graduate and undergraduate students in OR and Data Science were exposed to non-traditional applications of operations research through their involvement in the project.   Insights from this research project were incorporated into undergraduate operations research courses.

 

6)       Review of the current state of research in the nexus of human-trafficking and OR. 

 

7)       Identification of human trafficking features needing to be incorporated into analytical models. Informed by the interdisciplinary collaboration and data, the team identified aspects of human trafficking that need to be considered in any responsible OR research. The findings are summarized in a manuscript (under review at the time of writing). The team also set a future research agenda for the OR and Analytics community.

 

Our research provided answers to the following ?What features of human trafficking need to be incorporated into OR and Analytical models?? By addressing this question, our research has the potential to spur further studies in the application and development of data science approaches and OR methods to combat human trafficking.
